org.apache.tephra.inmemory

Class DetachedTxSystemClient

  • java.lang.Object
    • org.apache.tephra.inmemory.DetachedTxSystemClient
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    TransactionSystemClient

    public class DetachedTxSystemClient
extends Object
implements TransactionSystemClient
    Implementation of the tx system client that doesn't talk to any global service and tries to do its best to meet the tx system requirements/expectations. NOTE: Will NOT detect conflicts. May leave inconsistent state when process crashes. Does NOT provide even read isolation guarantees. Good for performance testing. For demoing high throughput. For use-cases with relaxed tx guarantees.

      • canCommit

        public boolean canCommit(Transaction tx,
                         Collection<byte[]> changeIds)
        Description copied from interface: TransactionSystemClient
        Checks if transaction with the set of changes can be committed. E.g. it can check conflicts with other changes and refuse commit if there are conflicts. It is assumed that no other changes will be done in between this method call and TransactionSystemClient.commitOrThrow(Transaction) which will check conflicts again to avoid races.

        Since we do conflict detection at commit time as well, this may seem redundant. The idea is to check for conflicts before we persist changes to avoid rollback in case of conflicts as much as possible. NOTE: in some situations we may want to skip this step to save on RPC with a risk of many rollback ops. So by default we take safe path.

        Specified by:
        canCommit in interface TransactionSystemClient
        Parameters:
        tx - transaction to verify
        changeIds - ids of changes made by transaction
        Returns:
        true if transaction can be committed otherwise false

      • canCommitOrThrow

        public void canCommitOrThrow(Transaction tx,
                             Collection<byte[]> changeIds)
        Description copied from interface: TransactionSystemClient
        Checks if transaction with the set of changes can be committed. E.g. it can check conflicts with other changes and refuse commit if there are conflicts. It is assumed that no other changes will be done in between this method call and TransactionSystemClient.commitOrThrow(Transaction) which will check conflicts again to avoid races.

        Since we do conflict detection at commit time as well, this may seem redundant. The idea is to check for conflicts before we persist changes to avoid rollback in case of conflicts as much as possible. NOTE: in some situations we may want to skip this step to save on RPC with a risk of many rollback ops. So by default we take safe path.

        Specified by:
        canCommitOrThrow in interface TransactionSystemClient
        Parameters:
        tx - transaction to verify
        changeIds - ids of changes made by transaction

      • abort

        public void abort(Transaction tx)
        Description copied from interface: TransactionSystemClient
        Makes transaction visible. You should call it only when all changes of this tx are undone. NOTE: it will not throw TransactionNotInProgressException if transaction has timed out.
        Specified by:
        abort in interface TransactionSystemClient
        Parameters:
        tx - transaction to make visible.

      • invalidate

        public boolean invalidate(long tx)
        Description copied from interface: TransactionSystemClient
        Makes transaction invalid. You should call it if not all changes of this tx could be undone. NOTE: it will not throw TransactionNotInProgressException if transaction has timed out.
        Specified by:
        invalidate in interface TransactionSystemClient
        Parameters:
        tx - transaction id to invalidate.
        Returns:
        true if transaction has been successfully invalidated

      • checkpoint

        public Transaction checkpoint(Transaction tx)
        Description copied from interface: TransactionSystemClient
        Performs a checkpoint operation on the current transaction, returning a new Transaction instance with the updated state. A checkpoint operation assigns a new write pointer for the current transaction.
        Specified by:
        checkpoint in interface TransactionSystemClient
        Parameters:
        tx - the current transaction to checkpoint
        Returns:
        an updated transaction instance with the new write pointer
